Subject: Re: [cantera] Cantera153 segmentation fault

Gianfilippo,

The problem is that helium has such a small Lennard-Jones well depth  
that the non-dimensional temperature needed to compute the fits to the  
collision integrals for the transport properties goes outside the range  
of the tabulated values used to generate the fits (T* > 100). Cantera  
is supposed to handle this case cleanly, but it seems it is failing.   
The workaround is to specify in the cti file "transport = 'CK_Mix',",  
rather than "transport = 'Mix',".  This changes the algorithm used to  
set the temperature range for the fits so that the fit is always done  
with T*=100 as the upper limit, and T*=0.1 as the lower limit.  It also  
changes other options to make computation of transport properties as  
close as possible to the algorithm used by Chemkin, even at the expense  
of accuracy (using lower-order polynomial fits).  This bug will be  
fixed in the upcoming release (within a few days), and will be fixed in  
the development version in the CVS repository within the next hour.

Dave


fits of the collision integrals for the transport properties go out of  
the range of the tables used to

On May 21, 2004, at 9:16 AM, gfcoppola wrote:

> Dear Goodwin,
>
> I am now trying to run Cantera with the GRI30 'modified' to
> take into account Helium.
> I produced the 'modified' gri30.cti using the command line utility
> ch2cti and the resulting file is produced without error messages.
> When I try to run the Python demo file "npflame1" or the Matlab demo
> file "diffflame", with the following lines
> gas = importPhase('gri30He.cti')
> or
> gas = IdealGasMix('gri30He.cti')
> instead of
> gas = GRI30('Mix')
> the result is a segmentation fault.
> Do you have any suggestion ?
>
> Many thanks
> Gianfilippo Coppola
